questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a rule of ownership in Rust?

options.text: There can be multiple owners at a time
Value is dropped when the owner goes out of scope
There can only be one owner at a time

questions.explanation: Rust strictly enforces that there can only be one owner for a piece of data at any given time.

questions.question: What happens to a 'String' when you assign it to another variable (let s2 = s1)?
questions.explanation: For heap-allocated data like String, assignment moves the ownership to the new variable, making the old one invalid.

questions.question: Which memory area is used for data with a fixed, known size at compile time?
questions.explanation: The stack is used for data whose size is fixed and known when the code is compiled.

questions.question: How can you manually duplicate heap data (like a String) instead of moving it?
questions.explanation: The .clone() method creates a deep copy of the heap data.

questions.question: What happens to a variable's value when the variable goes out of scope?

options.text: It stays in memory until the program ends
It moves to the global scope

questions.explanation: Rust automatically calls a special 'drop' function to return the memory when an owner's scope ends.
